utterances: How long have you lived there?
A year.
A year...
Yep.
In this house?
Yep.
So I imagine you've never seen anything like this before?
No.
My brother was in the Scripps Ranch Fire - three, four years ago.
And I went up and helped him get stuff out if his house.
And now, of course, he moved here, and now he's in the middle of this one.
So you sound like you're not terribly afraid of being there with the flames?
Oh, no, no. Once the kids got out of the house, I'm fine.
So how long you're going to stay there?
I'm staying.
I'm not going.
I'm - I'm staying here for the - until there's flames next door, I'm going to stay here.
Do you have a mask or - what do you have?
I just have a respirator.
A respirator?
Yeah.
Home Depot.
I got the last one Saturday night at Home Depot.
So describe your property.
Is it in a wooded area?
Yeah.
It's - I don't know, I wouldn't call it wooded but there are a lot of trees here.
The average lot size is half an acre.
There are lot of pine trees, there's lot of Cyprus trees.
It's called green valley - a lot of trees.
And had you done any clearance recently?
Well, we just bought it a year and a half ago.
And so, we've been clearing it constantly because I do not know what he did anything for 40 years.
So we've been - we've cleared out tons and tons of underbrush and trees in the last year.
Our house is actually pretty safe compared to most of them around the area.
All dirt because we're going to build a bigger house and so, we've been preparing it for that.
So it's mostly surrounded by dirt.
And your wife and kids, where are they?
(unintelligible)They're in Oceanside in a Days Inn Hotel.
In a hotel?
Yep.
And did they not want you to go back to the house or did they...
Well, they didn't know I went.
They didn't?
No.
You just left in the middle of the night?
Yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's easier that way.
What did your wife say when she found out you've gone?
Oh, she knows.
She's fine.
She's - she's great.
She expects this sort of thing from me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Where we're at - we're in a small hotel room with two kids, two adults and two large German Shepherds - who weren't allowed in the hotel room but we had them there anyway.

And they got kind of restless about two o'clock, and so I said, I better get out of here with the dogs and so I took them to the beach and then decided I wanted to come and see what's going on down here.
Oh, it's good thing you did.
Yep.
Saved your brother's house.
(Soundbite of laughing)
Mark Pieroni, thank you for speaking with me.
I won't waste anymore of your cell phone minutes and...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thanks.
Good luck battling the fire.
Okay.
Bye.
Bye.
On Friday evening, Keith Olbermann surprised viewers of his ""Countdown"" program with a sudden and final sign-off.
The highest-rated host on MSNBC announced he was leaving his program effective immediately, and he offered no explanation except for this.
(Soundbite of TV show, ""Countdown with Keith Olbermann"")
There were many occasions, particularly in the last two and a half years, where all that surrounded this show - but never the show itself -was just too much for me.
Over the past eight years, Keith Olbermann's distinctive voice put MSNBC on the map of cable television.
He welcomed fights with his rivals at Fox News, and did more than anyone else to establish MSNBC as a liberal alternative.
